projects.title: FlashLearn
projects.description: We created a website for students to create flashcards based on any subject they need help with. As another feature, they can create questions and quizzes themselves to help strengthen their knowledge of the topic.
projects.technologies: We used three programming languages: HTML, CSS, and JavaScript. We chose these three languages because they are the simplest for website development and are very easy to learn. Since this is our first time making a website, we thought these languages would be best to use, due to their simplicity and functionality.

projects.title: Digital Task List
projects.description: This project allows students to input their upcoming tasks using the add task button, with information such as task name and due date being asked for. The code then sorts their tasks by date and puts this week's tasks in a weekly calendar. These tasks can by checked off in the upcoming tasks column or all of them being removed via the reset task list button. There is a dark and light mode coded into the program for one's preferences.
projects.technologies: We used the Python programming language due to its readability and being the only language we knew. It was accessed via VSCode and a virtual environment. We also used the StreamLit library of Python because it has a good web development tool for Python.

projects.title: Big Jim's Canvas
projects.description: Our project is a website that allows teachers to create and assign online assignments to students. Students can enter codes to see assignments and complete them.
projects.technologies: We used Python, an entry level programming language, and Streamlit, a Python extension which allow for the easy creation of websites.
projects.other: The title reflects the intersections of rural and technological themes.
